author: Diane Howard, Ph.D.
title: New movies sparking national reconcilation, redemption, revival
text:
Play Jon Voight talks to Colin Cowherd about playing the legendary Paul 'Bear' Bryant in the upcoming film 'Woodlawn.' on.aol.com These are exciting times as new independent, faith-based movies are sparking a growing movement of national reconciliation, redemption, and revival. Today, October 16, new reports , videos, and posters for the "Woodlawn" movie are widley available in various forms of media, as it opens in theaters today. USA Today reports , "With 'Woodlawn,' Christian films enter new playing field." The Lexington Herald reports , "New film recounts football team's faith after integration." Three independent, redemptive movies are currently in theaters, drawing racially diverse audiences who are standing to their feet in applause after showing in in cinemas.
"Woodlawn" has been released to theaters today. It’s about the reconciliation, redemption, and revival that broke out in a Birmingham, Alabama high school football and initiated a broader movement of reconciliation, redemption, and revival. This movie has already initiated a national movement like what happened in Birmingham and beyond. This week producer, Mark Burnett and Roma Downey, along with national leaders presented a national simulcast with a large audience entitled "Unify," in which they told of the original events, the story of the movie, and what is happening today as a result of the movie. At the end of the live event that was available on the WWW on a simulcast, hundreds of young people came to the front of the auditorium to positively stand with what had been presented. The movie features veteran actors Jon Voight ("National Treasure") and Sean Astin (Sam Gamgee in "Lord of the Rings").
"War Room" remains in theater after many weeks and was a one point the number one in the box office. It has a dominantly African American cast, who are skilled actors. It is based on the best-selling book by Priscilla Shirer. It is about the power of prayer to bring redemption, reconciliation, and reunification to a family in crisis and more. It has been the top-selling DVD, although it is still in pre-order, for many weeks in the African American and Drama categories. Audiences have been applauding at the end of showings and giving standing ovations.
"Captive" like "Woodlawn" and "War Room" has a racially diverse cast and has also drawn racially diverse audiences. It is based on the true story of the intense encounter of Ashley Smith and Brian Nichols. After Nichols took Smith captive in in her apartment, she opened Rick Warren's inspirational book, "The Purpose Driven Life.," which she had initially thrown away after it had been given as a gift. When Nichols asks her to read it to him, they both begin to experience the beginning of profoundly, positively, and eternally changing lives.
David Oyelowo (veteran British actor) who has beautifully played Martin Luther King in "Selma," skillfully plays Brian Nichols veteran British African actor) in the movie "Captive." David has given many wonderful interviews recently. Oyelowo has told how "God's Grace Can End Injustice & Hate" in an interview with Christian Cinema.com. He tells from the true story on which the movie is based shows how redemption and reconciliation are possible even with people of different racial backgrounds. David shares that his favorite part of the film is when Brian Nichols (African American) asks Ashley Smith (Caucasian) if "she could forgive him if he was the man who killed her husband." David tells that Ashley "doesn’t know if she could but she thinks that God could.” Oyelowo says that this moment was when Ashley's broke into her own salvation.
In the Christian Cinema.com interview, David Oyelowo says that the "miraculous breaks in, against our expectations..." Oyelowo states. “We really have to question our prejudices. Whether it’s in Selma or in the story of Brian Nichols, we have to treat people differently,” he said. Further, he says that what changed this situation was when Ashley Smith was willing to treat him like a human being as she read to Nichols and served him pancakes, and to treat him like a human being. Oyelowo tells, "She defused a human bomb" when she treated him "like he was human.”
In an exclusive interview with Austin Movie Examiner, Karen Abercrombie who plays the lead role of wise Aunt Clara in "War Room," said that the issues addressed in "War Room" have no color and. She told that what happens in the movie is universal to the human race. Exit polls show how "War Room" draws multi-racial audiences. The Kendrick Brothers, who wrote and produced "War Room," have reported that they deliberately chose a dominantly African-American cast for “War Room” to bring depth of spirit and soul. They want the movie to have honest, vulnerable, and broad appeal, as it focuses on the power of prayer.
In an exclusive interview with Austin Movie Examiner, Brian Bird, screenwriter for "Captive," said that all of us hunger for redemption and that redemptive movies point to the ultimate and original redemption story, which is critically needed for a time such as this.
With the many horrible riots and incidences of racial unrest and conflict in the United States and throughout the world, these movies are initiating, facilitating, and promoting a powerful, growing, much needed movement towards peaceful reconciliation, redemption and revival. Redemptive media can reach and change the world for Eternal Good and it is!
